modules.description: Computes ED25519 public keys from 32-byte secret keys and verifies or generates signatures using 32-byte keys. Operates on 32-byte raw key and message data, with signature validation requiring a 64-byte signature. Used to authenticate messages with cryptographic proof of origin using a predefined key pair.

Computes ED25519 public keys from 32-byte secret keys and verifies or generates signatures using 32-byte keys. Operates on 32-byte raw key and message data, ensuring cryptographic validity. Used to validate signed messages with a known public key or produce signatures with a precomputed key pair.

Converts bytes to hexadecimal buffers, parses hexadecimal buffers into 32-byte and 12-byte arrays, and handles encoding errors. Operates on byte buffers and individual byte elements. Used for cryptographic key parsing and network protocol data conversion.

Computes ED25519 public keys from 32-byte secret keys and generates or verifies 64-byte signatures on 32-byte messages using 32-byte keys. Provides functions to derive public keys, sign messages, and validate signatures with cryptographic assurance. Operations work directly with raw byte sequences, enabling secure authentication and message integrity checks. Examples include signing a transaction with a private key and verifying its authenticity using the corresponding public key.

Provides functions for key exchange, message encryption, and authentication using the KBB2017 protocol. Operates on cryptographic keys, session states, and encrypted message payloads. Enables secure communication channels in applications requiring end-to-end encryption and verified identities.

Encodes and decodes byte sequences to and from hexadecimal, supporting cryptographic key parsing and protocol data conversion through direct byte manipulation. Performs ED25519 cryptographic operations including public key derivation, message signing, and signature verification using raw byte inputs. Functions handle 32-byte and 12-byte arrays, enabling secure authentication and data integrity checks. Examples include converting a hexadecimal key to a 32-byte secret key, signing a message with a private key, and validating a signature using the associated public key.
